data.title: Every single Drew Barrymore movie, ranked
data.meta_description: Drew Barrymore is known for her roles in "50 First Dates" and "Grey Gardens," but she's also starred in movies like "Poison Ivy" and "Batman Forever."
data.text:
This story is available exclusively to Business Insider subscribers. Become an Insider and start reading now. Have an account? .

Drew Barrymore is known for her roles in award-winning movies like "50 First Dates."

Some of Barrymore's highest-rated films include "E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial" and "Grey Gardens."

Other films, like "Wishful Thinking" and "Batman Forever," didn't rate as well with critics.

Advertisement

Barrymore's lowest-rated film is "Wishful Thinking" (1997), in which she played Lena.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 0%

Summary: When a boyfriend (James Le Gros) isn't ready to settle down by marrying his girlfriend (Jennifer Beals), his coworker Lena (Barrymore) attempts to pursue him, leading to a series of complications.

Although some critics appreciated the film's quirky humor, most found it uneven.

"Too often wanders into unnecessary silliness, and the ending leaves something to be desired," wrote Dustin Putman for TheFilmFile.com.

Advertisement

She played Davidson's receptionist in "Freddy Got Fingered" (2001).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 11%

Summary: A struggling cartoonist's (Tom Green) bizarre and offensive antics disrupt his family's life.

Barrymore appeared in the film as a receptionist.

The movie was widely panned by critics for its crude humor and lack of coherence.

In a review for BBC, Danny Graydon wrote that the film was "embarrassing, offensive and resoundingly pointless."

Advertisement

In "Bad Girls" (1994), the actor played Lilly Laronette.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 13%

Summary: Four women on the run from the law (Barrymore, Andie MacDowell, Mary Stuart Masterson, and Madeleine Stowe) form an unlikely bond as they navigate the challenges of the Old West.

Some critics said the film wasn't historically accurate and had lackluster storytelling.

"The worthwhile cast can't overcome bland storytelling and uninspired scripting," wrote Mike Massie for Gone With the Twins.

Advertisement

Hope was Barrymore's character in "Best Men" (1997).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 13%

Summary: A groom's (Luke Wilson) bumbling friends inadvertently get involved in a bank robbery on his wedding day.

Barrymore appeared in the film as Hope.

Critics across the board seemed to agree that the film was a mediocre comedy.

In a review for eFilmCritic.com, Scott Weinberg wrote that the movie was a "fairly witless romantic heist comedy combo."

Advertisement

In "Blended" (2014), she played Lauren Reynolds.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 15%

Summary: After a disastrous first date between two single parents Jim Friedman (Adam Sandler) and Lauren Reynolds (Barrymore), they find themselves on a joint family vacation in Africa.

Most reviewers criticized the film's approach to comedy with many saying it was boring.

"Bland on the one hand, tacky on the other, 'Blended' lives up to its name," Philippa Hawker wrote for The Age.

Advertisement

The star played Billie Offer in "Lucky You" (2007).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 28%

Summary: A talented poker player (Eric Bana) navigates the ups and downs of professional gambling while dealing with family issues.

In the film, Barrymore played Billie.

Most critics didn't like the movie because of its lack of originality.

"The beats here aren't bad, they're just slow, slight and rather predictable," wrote Anthony Quinn for The Independent.

Advertisement

In addition to playing Candy in "The Stand In" (2020), she was also an executive producer.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 29%

Summary: A Hollywood actress (Barrymore) hires her acting double (Sarah Jes Austell) to take over her life, leading to comedic and dramatic consequences.

Despite Barrymore's solid acting, critics agreed the film had an underdeveloped plot.

"This satire misfires," wrote Leslie Felperin for The Hollywood Reporter.

Advertisement

The actor was Casey Roberts in "Mad Love" (1995).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 31%

Summary: Two young lovers Matt (Chris O'Donnell) and Casey (Barrymore) embark on a passionate and destructive journey across the country.

The film had mixed reviews, but most critics felt like it was misguided.

"Despite the old-fashioned ideology, at least 'Mad Love' is good to look at," Eric Monder wrote for Film Journal International.

Advertisement

In "Home Fries" (1998), Barrymore played Sally Jackson.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 31%

Summary: Dorian (Wilson) hunts down his dead stepfather's pregnant mistress (Barrymore) and falls in love instantly.

Critics enjoyed the film's dark humor, but it received a lot of negative reviews for its tonal inconsistencies.

"A dark comedy that's artificially dark and is never very funny," wrote Alex Sandell for The Juicy Cerebellum.

Advertisement

She played Nancy Kendricks in "Duplex" (2003).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 35%

Summary: A couple's (Ben Stiller and Barrymore) dream home turns into a nightmare when they have to deal with the elderly (and seemingly indestructible) neighbor in their duplex (Eileen Essell).

Most critics felt the film missed its potential as a comedy.

"Gets old fast, and the pay-off disappoints," wrote Nell Minow for Common Sense Media.

Advertisement

Barrymore played Charlie McGee in "Firestarter" (1984).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 38%

Summary: A young girl with pyrokinetic abilities (Barrymore) becomes the target of a government agency seeking to harness her powers.

Critics found the film to be a poor adaptation of the Stephen King novel it was based on.

"'Firestarter' is promptly exposed as a derivative embarrassment of a conception," wrote Gary Arnold for The Washington Post.

Advertisement

The actor starred as Ivy in "Poison Ivy" (1992).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 39%

Summary: A seductive and manipulative teenager (Barrymore) disrupts a family's life as she becomes involved with both the father (Tom Skerritt) and daughter (Sara Gilbert).

Critics didn't enjoy the film's exploitative elements, and some felt the plot on a whole was boring.

"By the time the climax approaches, ever so slowly, feeling as if hours longer than it is, the acting weakens and the revelations pale," wrote Mike Massie for Gone With the Twins.

Advertisement

In "Batman Forever" (1995), Barrymore played Sugar.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 40%

Summary: Batman (Val Kilmer) faces off against Two-Face (Tommy Lee Jones) and The Riddler (Jim Carrey) while dealing with his inner demons.

Barrymore appeared in the film as Sugar, one of Two-Face's love interests.

Most critics felt the movie departed from the darker tone of previous Batman films.

"It overdoes, overkills. And what starts out exhilarating ends up ... exhausting," wrote Carol Buckland for CNN.

Advertisement

In "Beverly Hills Chihuahua" (2008), she was the voice of Chloe.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 40%

Summary: A pampered Chihuahua from Beverly Hills (voiced by Barrymore) gets lost in Mexico and embarks on a journey to find her way back home.

Some reviewers enjoyed the film's family-friendly humor, but others found it formulaic.

"It's hugely silly, but peppy enough to be tolerable," wrote Anna Smith for Empire magazine.

Advertisement

The actor produced "Charlie's Angels: Full Throttle" (2003) and starred as Dylan Sanders.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 41%

Summary: The trio of iconic and glamorous private investigators (Barrymore, Cameron Diaz, and Alex Munday) return for another action-packed adventure.

The reboot of the classic franchise was praised for its action sequences but received criticism for its thin plot.

"This is one of the silliest movies ever made," wrote David Ansen for Newsweek. "Lots of instantly forgettable fun."

Advertisement

The star was executive producer of "He's Just Not That Into You" (2009) and appeared as Mary.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 41%

Summary: A group of interconnected individuals in Baltimore navigate the complexities of modern dating.

In the movie, Barrymore appeared as Mary.

Although some reviewers appreciated the film's relationship insights, others found it underwhelming.

"Though the actors involved are mostly major players, the material they've been given to work with is very old hat," wrote David Stratton for The Australian.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Rosie was Barrymore's character in "Everybody's Fine" (2009).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 47%

Summary: A widowed man (Robert De Niro) embarks on a journey to reconnect with his adult children (Barrymore, Kate Beckinsale, and Sam Rockwell) after they cancel a family reunion.

Some reviewers weren't fans of the film's sentimentality, but others recognized the talent of the cast.

Riese Bernard wrote for Autostraddle, "'Everybody's Fine' balances humor and drama in a familial odyssey anchored by compelling performances."

Advertisement

She played Beverly Donofrio in "Riding in Cars With Boys" (2001).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 49%

Summary: A young mother (Barrymore) reflects on life's ups and downs in her memoir, including her struggles as a teenage parent.

Barrymore's performance was applauded, but there was widespread criticism for the film's uneven storytelling.

"Not a great movie," wrote Minow for Common Sense Media. "Although Drew Barrymore shines."

Advertisement

In "Titan A.E." (2000), Barrymore was the voice of Akima.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 50%

Summary: In a post-apocalyptic future, a young man named Cale Tucker (Matt Damon) embarks on a journey to find a spaceship that could save humanity.

In the film, Barrymore was the voice of Akima.

Reviewers in favor of "Titan A.E." loved the cast, animation, and effects, but those who disliked it said it wasn't original enough.

"Despite individual moments that are extraordinarily rich in space opera bravado, the film as a whole is simply too stiff and awkward," wrote Tim Brayton for Alternate Ending.

Advertisement

The actor played Erin in "Going the Distance" (2010).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 54%

Summary: A long-distance relationship puts Erin (Barrymore) and Garrett's (Justin Long) love and commitment to the test.

Critics enjoyed the chemistry between the leads but thought it relied too heavily on romantic-comedy tropes.

"Unfortunately, 'Going the Distance' doesn't take audiences far enough," wrote Candice Frederick for Reel Talk Online.

Advertisement

The star was an executive producer of "Never Been Kissed" (1999) and played Josie Geller.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 55%

Summary: Journalist Josie Geller (Barrymore) goes undercover as a high-school student to report on teenage life. But along the way, she finds unexpected love.

The film received positive reviews for its charming cast and heartfelt coming-of-age story.

In a review for Common Sense Media, Minow wrote that the film was "a genuinely sweet and romantic story for teens."

Advertisement

Barrymore was Cathy Goodwin in "See You in the Morning" (1989).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 55%

Summary: Two widowed parents, Larry (Jeff Bridges) and Beth (Farrah Fawcett), navigate the complexities of love and family as they blend their households.

Barrymore played Beth's daughter, Cathy.

The movie received split reviews, with some critics appreciating its exploration of family dynamics and others finding it melodramatic.

"The screenplay is so scrupulous, so fair, so enlightened and so intelligent that real people have trouble shouldering it aside so that they can share messy human emotions," wrote Roger Ebert for the Chicago Sun-Times.

Advertisement

"Irreconcilable Differences" (1984) featured Barrymore as Casey Brodsky.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 60%

Summary: A custody battle over Casey (Barrymore) unfolds as the young girl sues her parents (Ryan O'Neal and Shelley Long) for divorce.

Critics enjoyed Barrymore's performance but felt the film's tone was uneven.

"One of the funnier and more intelligent movies of 1984," wrote Ebert for the Chicago Sun-Times.

Advertisement

"Motorama" (1991) showcased Barrymore as a fantasy girl.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 60%

Summary: A young boy named Gus (Jordan Christopher Michael) embarks on a surreal road trip to collect a series of game cards and win a valuable prize.

Barrymore appeared as a fantasy girl in Gus' daydreams.

The film was considered unique and offbeat by most reviewers.

"Everything that happens in this film is possible but that doesn't by necessity make any of it believable," wrote critic Shane Burridge.

Advertisement

In the sequel "Wayne's World 2" (1993), the actor played Bjergen Kjergen.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 60%

Summary: Wayne (Mike Myers) and Garth (Garth Algar) return for another round of comical misadventures, including a quest to organize a music festival.

Barrymore played Bjergen Kjergen, a receptionist.

The film was well-reviewed for its humor and nostalgia but was criticized for being less fresh than the original.

"Sometimes too familiar," wrote Janet Maslin for The New York Times. "But the formula isn't tired yet."

Advertisement

She was the voice of the titular character in "Olive, the Other Reindeer" (1999).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 60%

Summary: A dog named Olive (voiced by Barrymore) believes she can save Christmas when Santa Claus (voiced by Edward Asner) announces he needs more reindeer.

The movie received positive reviews for its cute animation and unique take on the classic holiday story.

"More of a silly wintertime adventure than a saccharine holiday movie," wrote Allegra Frank for The Daily Beast.

Advertisement

Barrymore was Anita Minteer in "Guncrazy" (1992).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 63%

Summary: Inspired by the 1950 original, a troubled teenager (Barrymore) and an ex-convict (Le Gros) embark on a crime spree and a passionate romance.

Although most critics appreciated the movie's dark themes, some found it disturbing.

"Doesn't even touch the original classic," wrote Steve Crum for the Kansas City Kansan. "But still edgy."

Advertisement

Sophie Fisher was her character's name in "Music and Lyrics" (2007).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 63%

Summary: A washed-up singer (Hugh Grant) and a quirky artist (Barrymore) team up to write a hit song for a reigning pop star (Haley Bennett).

Critics praised the film's charm and chemistry between its lead actors.

"Light, sweet, and agreeably confident," wrote Michael Phillips for The Chicago Tribune.

Advertisement

She was a producer of "Fever Pitch" (2005) and played Lindsey Meeks.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 66%

Summary: Ben's (Jimmy Fallon) obsession with the Boston Red Sox becomes a hurdle in his budding romance with Lindsey (Barrymore).

Most reviewers enjoyed the sports-themed rom-com, but some criticized it for its predictability.

"The film turns out to be a substantial pleasure as the spirit of the Sox shines through," wrote Joe Morgenstern for The Wall Street Journal.

Advertisement

Barrymore was a producer of "Charlie's Angels" (2000) and played Dylan Sanders.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 68%

Summary: A trio of female detectives (Barrymore, Diaz, and Munday) take on dangerous missions with style, humor, and action.

Reviews of the remake were mostly positive because of its entertainment value and the chemistry between its leads.

"Much of the film's continued appeal comes down to the magical performances of its leads," wrote Anne Cohen for Refinery29.

Advertisement

In "Cat's Eye" (1985), Barrymore played Amanda.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 69%

Summary: A cat appears as a common thread between three different Stephen King horror stories.

In the film, Barrymore appeared as a young girl named Amanda.

Although most critics appreciated the adaptation of King's stories, others found it uneven.

"It's the anthology film I wish 'Twilight Zone: The Movie' could have been," wrote Felix Vasquez Jr. for Cinema Crazed.

Advertisement

The star voiced Maggie in "Curious George" (2006).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 70%

Summary: Curious George (voiced by Frank Welker), a lovable and courageous monkey, explores the world and learns valuable lessons from Ted, also known as The Man With the Yellow Hat (voiced by Will Ferrell).

Barrymore was the voice of Maggie, Ted's love interest.

Critics appreciated the family-friendly animation based on the beloved children's books for its timeless appeal.

"It's a gentle, unhurried, largely hand-drawn children's cartoon with a nice simple storyline and no nods and winks to the grown-ups," Steve Rose wrote for The Guardian.

Advertisement

The actor was Jess in "Miss You Already" (2015).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 71%

Summary: The lifelong friendship of two women (Barrymore and Toni Collette) is put to the test when one of them faces a life-threatening illness.

Most critics enjoyed the movie's exploration of friendship and illness.

"A 'Beaches'-style exploration of women's friendship," wrote Minow for AWFJ.org.

Advertisement

In "The Wedding Singer" (1998), she starred as Julia Sullivan.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 72%

Summary: A wedding singer with a broken heart (Sandler) finds hope for love when he meets a charming waitress (Barrymore).

Reviewers liked the film's '80s nostalgia, humor, and sweet relationships between characters.

"At its best, it is a gentle, well-portrayed, feel good film," wrote Ali Barclay for BBC.

Advertisement

Advertisement

In "Boys on the Side" (1995), Barrymore played Holly.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 73%

Summary: Three women with different backgrounds (Barrymore, Whoopi Goldberg, and Mary-Louise Parker) form an unlikely bond on a cross-country road trip.

Most reviewers said they enjoyed the movie's exploration of friendship and adversity.

"An engagingly acted, likable, fried green 'Thelma & Louise,'" wrote Rita Kempley for The Washington Post.

Advertisement

The actor starred in "Big Miracle" (2012) as Rachel Kramer.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 74%

Summary: A news reporter (John Krasinski) works with activists and the military to save a family of trapped whales in the Arctic Circle.

Barrymore appeared as Rachel Kramer, an environmental activist.

Critics admired the film's heartwarming story and solid acting.

"'Big Miracle' has all the important elements required to deliver a heartfelt family drama," wrote Francesca Rudkin for the New Zealand Herald.

Advertisement

Barrymore appeared as herself in "A Castle for Christmas" (2021).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 74%

Summary: A famous author (Brooke Shields) buys a Scottish castle and gets more than she bargained for when she becomes entangled in local affairs.

Barrymore made a cameo in the Netflix-original film.

Critics widely considered the film to be a light and charming holiday romance.

"'A Castle For Christmas' is gently disarming, heartening, holiday-themed escapism that's as satisfying as a cup of hot chocolate on a cold winter's night," wrote Courtney Howard for Variety.

Advertisement

Advertisement

The star played Penny in "Confessions of a Dangerous Mind" (2002).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 80%

Summary: Based on a true story, the movie showcases the bizarre life of Chuck Barris (Rockwell), a game-show producer who claimed to be a CIA assassin.

In the movie, Barrymore played Barris' love interest, Penny.

It was largely applauded for its darkly comedic take on Barris' life.

"The film does not offer any explanations," wrote Namrata Joshi for Outlook. "Instead, it intrigues more."

Advertisement

In the horror film "Scream" (1996), Barrymore played Casey Becker.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 81%

Summary: A small town is terrorized by a masked killer who targets high-school students.

Barrymore appeared in the film as Casey Becker.

"Scream" received widespread acclaim for revitalizing the horror genre with its clever commentary and suspenseful thrills.

"Through reinvention and self-awareness, 'Scream' brought the slasher genre to new, fun, and bloody heights," wrote Kristy Strouse for Wonderfully Weird and Horrifying.

Advertisement

"Altered States" (1980) showcased the actor as Margaret Jessup.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 85%

Summary: A scientist's (William Hurt) experiments with sensory deprivation lead to bizarre and transformative experiences.

Barrymore played Margaret Jessup, the scientist's daughter.

Critics loved the movie's visuals and exploration of altered consciousness.

"Exciting, powerful and frightening, this sci-fi action flick is a near-masterpeice," wrote Larry Vitacco for Philadelphia Gay News.

Advertisement

She wrote and directed "Whip It" (2009), in addition to playing Smashley Simpson.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 85%

Summary: A young woman (Elliot Page) rebels against her beauty-pageant obsessed mother by joining a Roller Derby team.

Along with writing and directing "Whip It," Barrymore appeared as Smashley Simpson.

The film was highly reviewed for its empowering message and Page's performance.

"It's a funny, feel good, feminist film that throws elbows, pulls no punches and features a fantastic food fight," wrote Alex Behan for Stuff.

Advertisement

She was Ms. Karen Pomeroy in "Donnie Darko" (2001).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 87%

Summary: Donnie Darko (Jake Gyllenhaal) experiences strange visions and encounters a mysterious rabbit figure while navigating a surreal and thought-provoking journey.

Barrymore played Karen Pomeroy, one of Darko's life guides.

The film received critical acclaim for its mind-bending narrative, psychological depth, and Gyllenhaal's exceptional performance.

"'Donnie Darko' defines itself through sustained mood, otherworldly intrigue, and deep, abiding humanism," wrote Nick Schager for Lessons of Darkness.

Advertisement

"Grey Gardens" (2009) featured the star as Little Edie.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 88%

Summary: Based on a true story, this film explores the eccentric lives of Edith Bouvier Beale (Jessica Lange) and her daughter Little Edie (Barrymore), relatives of Jackie Kennedy (Jeanne Tripplehorn).

The movie was recognized for its cast and fascinating portrait of the Beales and their lifestyle.

"Whatever problems I had with the script for 'Grey Gardens' are completely offset by the stunning performances by Lange and Barrymore," wrote Brian Tallerico for HollywoodChicago.com.

Advertisement

In the documentary "Who Are You, Charlie Brown?" (2021), the actor appeared as herself.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 89%

Summary: The animated special celebrates the enduring legacy of the Peanuts characters and their creator, Charles M. Schulz.

Barrymore was one of the celebrities interviewed in the documentary.

Most critics enjoyed the film's nostalgic tribute to the beloved franchise.

"'Who Are You, Charlie Brown?' is a suitably warm and breezy love letter," wrote Richard Roeper for the Chicago Sun-Times.

Advertisement

In "Ever After: A Cinderella Story" (1998), Barrymore played Danielle de Barbarac.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 91%

Summary: Danielle de Barbarac (Barrymore) takes charge of her own destiny in this reimagined "Cinderella" tale set in Renaissance-era France.

Reviewers liked the feminist twist on the classic fairy tale, and Barrymore's acting was well-reviewed.

"Barrymore continues to prove herself as a performer of extraordinary range and charisma, and is simply sublime in the leading role," Leonard Klady wrote for Variety.

Advertisement

Barrymore played Gertie in "E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial" (1982), her highest-rated film.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 99%

Summary: A young boy named Elliott (Henry Thomas) befriends an alien stranded on Earth and helps him return home while evading government agents.

Barrymore played Gertie, Elliott's younger sister.

The film is celebrated for its heartwarming story, Steven Spielberg's direction, and an iconic portrayal of friendship.

"'E.T.' is worth standing in line for," wrote Scott Cain for the Atlanta Journal-Constitution. "Steven Spielberg's story is the essence of fairy-tale simplicity."

Note: All scores were current on the date of publication and are subject to change. Films without critical ratings were not included.

When you buy through our links, Insider may earn an affiliate commission. Learn more.
